instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - powercycling
threads.message:
Hi,
i got a MABP 15" 2014 that came with some mechanical damage... looked like somebody scratched over the board and ripping out components to prevent it from beeing repaired.
The ripped off components were: <RESISTOR>R1412</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1440</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1996</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1995</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1178</RESISTOR>, L7360, L8760, L8710, L3095, <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>. Some scratches are on the RAM chips <CHIP>U2350</CHIP> and <CHIP>U2550</CHIP>.
The rest of the board looks perfectly fine - the board was never removed from the case before and i dont see any further damage.
I replaced all components but the board (board alone only with battery and DC connected) gives me fan spin for few seconds then powering off again, turning on again for few seconds, turning off again, and so on...
I checked the big coils for shorts - didn't found any.

Any clue what could cause this?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - powercycling
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full"]60440[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]60441[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]60442[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full"]60443[/ATTACH]

Forgot to mention that CPU is getting voltage on fanspin. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not pulsing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - powercycling
threads.message:
Probably knocked off components in other areas.
Are you sure all traces are good and changed all needed components?
Which was the initial problem of the machine?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - powercycling
threads.message:
I will check the traces around <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> again. I checked the whole Board for more missing components but didn't found anything. 
I replaced all except the two RAM chips. Should I try to reflow these? 
Unfortunately I don't know anything about the history of this board. Maybe the knocked off components were the only problem ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - powercycling
threads.message: Just checked all rails around the ripped off components - they seem all good. Sometimes the boeard starts beeping, but the beep is cut off because it is tuning off again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - powercycling
threads.message: Intentionally damaged board, very likely waste of time...
